On Painting Well, or the Application of Colors.
The Twelfth Chapter

div.ab:
1. If drawing, in a manner of speaking,
is compared to the Body
with its different members,
then it is not inappropriate to compare
painting to the Spirit, or the Soul.
For through colors, the dead strokes
of drawing begin to stir and live
and are truly awakened.
left-middleDrawing compared to the body, and painting, to the spirit.

2. Indeed, drawing is like the Clay statue
made by Prometheus, which displeased
Minerva, Goddess of the Arts.
But painting is like the Celestial fire he stole
he stole, and with which–to his own destruction–
he endowed his work with movement,
and in time it became Pandora,
the abundance of all good things.
left-middleDrawing compared to Prometheus’ rough statue, and painting to Celestial fire.

3. Not unlike it, but precisely the same manner
that Poets, when singing, to beguile the ear,
marry their verses and their poems to the lyre
or another instrument, we must do
likewise to gratify the sight,
uniting Drawing and Painting
just as strings are joined to voices.
left-middleDrawing compared to the sound of Instruments, and painting, to song.

4. I would not presume to say with praise or disdain
that some, who are well-practiced, experienced
of a firm hand, full of accomplishment,
(not easily wandering on winding paths,
but worthy of their Master's name in Art)
will swiftly trace straight on their panels
what was already painted in their Imagination
left-middleDrawing directly on the panel is the work of a Master.

5. and falling on it straightaway, without great effort,
with brush and paint, and a courageous heart.
And thus these companions in work, as they paint,
swiftly set down their forms in ground color,
then sometimes repaint at once
for a better composition. So those who are
rich in invention work boldly,
here and there correcting their faults.
